title: Storm-Anchor of Names

quest_giver.name: Veyla Prism
quest_giver.affiliation: Independent glass-cartographer, informally allied with the Rookery of Aerie Pilots

description: Beyond the outer rib where the shade-netting ends, the Saltglass Expanse rolls in frozen waves of green-blue, a petrified sea still listening for thunder like a lover waiting on a letter. Fulgurite spires spear the sky, each a lightning-sculpted organ pipe that shivers when a spoken name strikes it in a matching key, and under each footfall the dunes hiss as if whispering an argument between heat and wind. Veyla Prism moves like a stitch of color across the glare, scarf tied at her brow, glass-reader's eyes scanning the horizons for the mirrored ridges where Syndicate escorts crouch with their kites reefed and their patience trimmed sharp. The storm-anchor rises ahead, a monolith of fused strikes polished by a century of storms until it reflects the world in a crooked truth; even at a distance it hums, an almost-voice clearing its throat before it tells a lie to the sky. Somewhere among the ridges waits Pera Thass with her smile like a polished shard, her memory full of bought names, her hands ready to draw a storm to the Resonant Gate by speaking 'Marrowhold' thrice in a key taught by coin and cruelty. If the rite completes, the Gate will sing a welcoming chord to a fire wearing rain's clothing, and the city will bow under a test it did not ask for and could not forgive. Rogan Kettlebone, bearing bone-lamellar scoured by glass winds and a fulgurite sabre that crackles quiet hunger, must sever the resonance before the name tethers the storm, steal proof in a shard that hums the false note, and flee across panes thinner than pride before a glass wyrm rises to remind men that the titan still dreams of oceans.
objectives: Reach the fulgurite monolith with Veyla Prism and map the storm-anchor’s hum using the cullet thread without alerting the Syndicate escorts.
Eavesdrop on Pera Thass and the Saltglass Syndicate technicians to learn the exact trigger rite and the key needed to speak Marrowhold’s name.
Prevent the speaking of Marrowhold’s name in the correct key or else sabotage the anchor’s resonance so that the rite fails even if attempted.
Survive a glass wyrm’s breach long enough to finish the sabotage and escape the shatter-zone.
Collect a fulgurite shard that carries the Gate’s false note as physical evidence of the plot.

dialogue.speaker: Veyla Prism
dialogue.lines: Keep your steps light and your voice lighter, Rogan, for the glass hears more than ears and stores it like winter water in a private well. These ridges look empty, but they are crowded with echoes, and an echo here will sell you cheap to a storm if you let it borrow your name. The anchor ahead is the kind that pretends to be a monument, but it is a tool, and tools always have an owner even when the owner thinks the sky works on tips. I want your patience more than your sabre until we know the key, because if we sing wrong to this stone it will teach us the right note with broken bones. Walk with me in the shadow of the fulgurite and think thoughts you do not mind the wind learning word for word.

dialogue.speaker: Pera Thass
dialogue.lines: Hear me, boys on the ridge, and keep your mirrors steady, because we are about to show the city that weather can be bought by the careful and sold to the desperate. We will speak the city’s name gently, as if waking a child from a good dream, and the sky will rise to kiss our hands like a debtor greeting a lender in the marketplace. Some will call it blasphemy and some will call it science, but I call it leverage, and leverage is the only prayer that never fails in Marrowhold. If your hearts are soft, harden them; if your tongues are heavy, lighten them; the key is not in your throats but in the way your fear leans. When the Gate answers us with a pretty hum, you’ll remember that a storm is only weather, and weather always belongs to the people who can afford to be wrong and still eat supper.

dialogue.speaker: Rogan Kettlebone
dialogue.lines: I have seen a storm peel the roof from a house and leave a cradle rocking under clear air as if the sky had mercy, and I have seen mercy used like a knife in the ration lines under the ribs. Do not tell me the weather loves anyone, Pera, because it only listens the way a wolf listens when you jingle meat at the edge of the camp. Step back from that monolith and count the cost twice, because once you pay in glass you will pay in blood and then again in names. You are not just aiming a cloud; you are teaching the Gate a lie, and lies told to bone do not forget to come home. Speak thrice if you dare, but hear this: the city you sell will remember the weight of your voice long after your coin is quiet.

dialogue.speaker: Syndicate Technician (Mask No. 4)
dialogue.lines: Set the cullet thread taut but not singing, and for the love of margins do not let it touch the monolith before the third name, because it will harmonize early and we will get a dry echo and no rain. Align your mirrors at forty-three breaths to the wind and adjust by a thumb’s width if the left ear hears more than the right, because the anchor leans toward the ridge with the broken kite post. The key is a child’s humming game, two notes above the Gate’s dawn bell, then one below, then hold your breath until your tongue stings like you tasted copper. When the lead calls the name, you answer it inside your teeth so the anchor thinks it is being loved from all sides, and if you hear the glass underfoot fizz it means the wyrm woke and we should pretend to be dunes. If a big man with a fulgurite tattoo on his shoulder shows up, that is the Watch-dog turned stray and you are to finish the rite anyway because Syndicate policy says storms do not wait for former uniforms.

dialogue.speaker: Veyla Prism
dialogue.lines: She is off-key by a breath, Rogan, and that is the kind of mistake that becomes a grave if we do not help it along with a shovel’s nudge. I can set a hand-mirror at a wrong angle and make the chord split like an old marriage, but I will need you to give them a reason to look away from the shine. Or you can cut the filament with that storm-sabre of yours and we will pray the wyrm prefers to eat songs instead of men today, though I have never seen a wyrm choose a melody over marrow. There is a third path that tastes like ash—I can feed Pera a false kindness and flatter her ear until she sings her own name into the anchor by mistake and the sky kisses nobody. Choose quickly but not foolishly; the hum is tightening, and the Gate will hear even the thought of the wrong note if we let it grow bold.

dialogue.speaker: Pera Thass
dialogue.lines: You, ogre-blooded, with your old Watch whistle clinking like a guilt around your neck, do you think a growl makes you free or just louder to the dogs who eat the scraps? I do not need to finish the rite to ruin you, because a rumor said softly into the ribs rolls farther than any echo you have ever chased. But make no mistake, I can finish it, and when I do I will be the only one dry while the city begs for towels and titles, and the Magistrate of Coin will sign receipts with my name braided through the ink. This is just business wrapped in thunder, and the Syndicate pays its debts better than the prayers you left behind at the temple door. Stand aside and let grown work be done, or stay and learn how to drown in a place where the rain burns like glass.

dialogue.speaker: Rogan Kettlebone
dialogue.lines: I have carried water under oaths and under curses, and both times it was heavy, but never as heavy as the quiet that comes after a preventable disaster. Look closely at your mirrors, Pera, because they are showing you a future where your name is a shard nobody can touch without bleeding, and that is not leverage, that is a wound. You say this is business, but business with the sky always ends with the sky collecting in full, and the ledger does not care whose numbers started the sum. You do not know the Gate the way the Watch does; it holds grudges like a grandmother and sings them into bone where they live forever. If you insist on a lesson, then here is mine: I will break your song, and I will do it without killing you, so you can hear the silence you tried to sell.

dialogue.speaker: Glass Wyrm (the breach)
dialogue.lines: The dune tightens the way a lip curls before a sneer, then puckers and opens like an eye waking to a room it already hates. A ring of glass collapses into a hollow breath, and the breath becomes a throat, and the throat becomes a mouth filled with light like drowned lightning. Sand becomes scales, and scales reflect a thousand broken versions of the sky, each one a little closer to the color of teeth. The wyrm rides its own echo up through the pane and the pane screams, and for a heartbeat everything smells of ozone and old rain and the first lie a child ever told. It tastes the chord in the air, decides the hunger can sleep if the song is ugly, and closes the dune again with a sigh like a cathedral door that will not open for that name anymore.

dialogue.speaker: Veyla Prism
dialogue.lines: It is done, and that deafness you hear in the stone is the absence of a door closing forever, which is a better silence than the sound of a city weeping. The anchor is dull where it used to be eager, and its shadow is honest again, the way shadows are supposed to be when the sun is not bribed. Take this fulgurite shard; it hums with the false note like a guilty man hums in a quiet room he cannot leave, and it will testify for us when words are called liars. Keep it tied tight against your oaths and do not show it to mirrors unless you want the Night-Glass to come sniffing with their black gloves and unpriced favors. I will map the broken chord and bury the map under a name that does not belong to anybody, because some cartography should not be bought.

dialogue.speaker: Rogan Kettlebone
dialogue.lines: Tell Zexi to watch the kites for a storm that goes looking for its name and finds none, because I want the Rookery ready to laugh when the sky forgets its lines. I will carry this shard to someone who can scrape the last of the lie off the Gate’s strings without breaking the ribs that hold the city up, and I will walk the long way so the echoes do not learn my route. The Syndicate will come howling with ledgers and hired throats, but their kind always confuses noise with proof, and this time we have a song they cannot afford. I do not say thank you lightly, Veyla, but I will say it once now and once later under a different sky, because you stood against the note and did not blink. If they come for you, speak my name to the wind in the key of a watch whistle, and I will hear it even if I am halfway to the Fen and thinking of debts.

choices.title: Splinter the Chord with Mirrors
choices.text: Veyla slips a thumb-sized mirror from her scarf and asks for your distraction as if she were asking for a drink of water, polite and without plea. You move with deliberate clumsiness, letting your boots squeal a little on the thinnest panes, and the Syndicate eyes tilt toward you as if pulled by a hook. Pera calls you a name meant to bruise, and you answer with a laugh that sounds like a stone rolling down a dry well, long enough for Veyla to set the mirror at a wrong angle where the anchor drinks its own echo. The monolith’s hum begins to bifurcate, two notes grinding like old teeth, and the key that once fit now slides uselessly against a lock that pretends not to exist. You feel the wind change its mind the way a liar changes a story mid-sentence, and for a moment you are sure the wyrm will come, but the dune only sighs like a disappointed tutor.
choices.outcome: The rite fails quietly, and the word Marrowhold spoken thrice in the chosen key finds no purchase, dissolving into harmless heat that blows toward the empty horizon. Pera understands too late that the chord was split not by strength but by a clever finger in the hinge of the song, and her smile turns brittle as kiln glass cooled too fast. The Syndicate escorts glare with the fury of men who were promised commissions and delivered only windburn, and you hear the sound of your name entering a ledger you will never be allowed to read. Veyla presses the tuned shard into your palm while the echo is still confused, and her map-scratchings mark where the chord now sleeps and should not be woken. You depart under a veil of ordinary silence, and though your back prickles with the thought of pursuit, the wyrm does not come, and the gate of the city will not be asked to sing a lie today.

choices.title: Sever the Cullet Filament with Lightning-Glass
choices.text: You choose the direct cut, because some knots are made of pride and only a blade will persuade them. The fulgurite sabre answers your grip with a small storm that lives along its edge, and when you draw it the air leans closer as if to hear a secret. You step once, twice, three times across panes that ring like brittle bells, and you slice the thread where its hum is brightest, a blue-white line that parts with the clean relief of truth told at last. The anchor screams in a voice only the bones of the dunes can understand, and the sound drags the wyrm up like a fish yanked by a memory. You and Veyla dive for a ridge as the dune opens, and the world becomes a gallery of teeth and mirrors and heat that paints your lungs with a taste of coins left too long in the mouth.
choices.outcome: The filament’s death unkeys the rite so completely that Pera’s third naming collapses into a cough, and the false storm staggers and wanders away like a drunk who lost the address. The glass wyrm’s breach is real and terrible, but it is brief; denied the clean song it came to swallow, the beast closes the dune with a grudging shudder and sinks back to the last dream of the titan like a child rolling over. Syndicate men scrabble for footing and excuses, and their fury hardens into a promise that will find you later in alleys and audits. Your coat’s bone-runes crack in two places, your shoulder throbs where an old fulgurite burn remembers its birth, and Veyla has a new scar that she will call a line of latitude and nothing else. In the sudden calm, the shard you retrieve from the filament’s severed end hums a counterfeit note so clear that even a temple novice would call it evidence, and you leave the Expanse with the storm’s leash snapped and dangling from your hand.

choices.title: Name-Bargain and Miskey the Rite
choices.text: You walk into the open with your hands away from your sabre and your voice low, and you speak to Pera like a man speaks to another person’s mirror: careful, curious, and ready to put it down if it cuts. You tell her a truth she wants to believe—that you can make the city’s name sweeter to the anchor if she lets you add a ribbon of breath from the Whisper Fen, a memory of cool water braided through the syllables. You speak of how the Gate loves old stories best when they are told in new ways, and you offer to teach a variant key that shifts one note closer to flattery and two away from fidelity. Pera, being Pera, loves the compliment more than the caution and commits to the miskey with ambition shining in her teeth, and she orders her men to keep their mirrors steady while she duets with your deception. Veyla, understanding the game, feeds a glancing flash into the wrong angle, and the anchor drinks the dressed-up name as if it were wine made of vinegar and decides to spit instead of swallow.
choices.outcome: The miskeyed rite unravels elegantly, leaving Pera convinced for one hot minute that she succeeded before the monolith releases a hollow, harmless cough that will never be rain. Her men argue about calibration while she argues about betrayal with the empty air, and the window in which she could have blamed you closes when she realizes she sang the mistake herself. The storm never takes the leash because the leash was made of compliments, and compliments are poor rope in the teeth of weather that expects to be commanded. You collect a shard tuned to the false note from the monolith’s cooled edge, its hum a small, steady confession that will play well in the ears of any honest arbiter or clever blackmailer. The Saltglass Syndicate will sour at the taste of this humiliation and will remember your face the way a kiln remembers a burn, but Veyla will remember your restraint and your cunning, and the Rookery rumors will tilt ever so slightly in your favor.

rewards.description: Fulgurite Shard tuned to the false note—an audible proof that the storm-anchor was bent toward a lie and now sings a counterfeit harmony when tested beside the Resonant Gate.
Soured relations with the Saltglass Syndicate; their ledgers now carry your name in a margin where favors are not granted and storms are considered assets.
Veyla Prism’s ongoing assistance across glass terrains; she will guide you through the Expanse’s hums and mirages, and her maps will bend toward your needs when the dunes would prefer you lost.
